title-group.article-title: The relationship between Index of Complexity, Outcome and Need, and patients' perceptions of malocclusion: a study in general dental practice
title-group.subtitle: General Practice

body.p: With the ever-increasing importance of clinical effectiveness and audit, the only way of ensuring the proper undertaking of evidence-based research on a large scale is to standardize methods of measurement. Indices have been used for a long time to standardize methods of measurement, thus facilitating comparisons when conducting epidemiological surveys in populations. Furthermore, they have been used to objectively assess the need for treatment to maximize benefit from limited resources.

sec.title: Aim
sec.p: To examine the relationship between ICON and the subjective opinions of patients attending for routine dental care.

list-item.p: To calibrate examiners to an acceptable level of reliability.
To determine the subjective opinions of 11–14 and 30–40 year olds with respect to aesthetics, function, speech and treatment need.
To highlight the differences in ICON scores between the two age groups, and the two genders.
To determine the strength of association between the ICON and patients' subjective opinions.
To determine the sensitivity and specificity of the ICON with respect to treatment need.

app.title: Appendix 1 ICON – Index of Complexity, Outcome and Need

list-item.p: Based on expert opinion of 97 practising specialist orthodontists from Germany, Greece, Hungary, Italy, Netherlands, Norway, Spain, United Kingdom and the USA
For use on patients or dental casts
A single assessment method to record complexity, outcome and need
For use in clinical governance, audit, research and decision making
Five components, taking about 1 minute to measure

app.p: The aesthetic component was first published as a scan. Evans R, Shaw W C. A Preliminary evaluation of an illustrated scale for rating dental attractiveness Eur J Orthod, 1987; 9:314-318.

list-item.p: The difference between the sum of the mesio-distal tooth diameters and the available arch circumference in the upper arch reduced to a 5-point score

Impacted teeth in either arch immediately score 5. Impacted teeth must be unerupted and either:
Ectopic or impacted against an adjacent tooth (excluding third molars but including supernumerary teeth)
Possess less than or equal to 4 mm of space between the adjacent permanent teeth. Use average canine and premolar widths to estimate the potential crowding in the mixed dentition, namely, 7 mm for pre-molars, lower canine, and 8 mm for upper canine
Spacing in one part of the arch will cancel out crowding elsewhere
Retained deciduous teeth (without permanent successor) and erupted supernumerary teeth score as space (unless they are to be retained to obviate the need for prosthesis)
Lost teeth caused by trauma or extraction should be counted as space (unless space is maintained for a prosthetic replacement).
Anterior and posterior transverse discrepancies of cusp to cusp or greater m intercuspal position
Open bite (except developmental conditions) is measured to the mid-incisal edges
Deep bite is measured to deepest part of overbite
If both traits are present only the highest score is counted
Quality of buccal segment interdigitation is measured (not Angle's classification)
Both sides are scored then added together
